action.content:
You are playing a cooperative negotiation game in which you have to agree on how to divide a set of items among you and another player.

Rules:
(a) You and the other player are given a set of items. Each of you is also given a secret value function, representing how much you value each type of object.
(b) You exchange messages with the other player to agree on who gets which items. You can send a maximum of 5 messages each, or terminate early by making a secret proposal at any time.
(c) You are each asked to submit a secret proposal indicating the items you want formatted in square brackets as follows: "[Proposal: <number> <object name>, <number> <object name>, <...>]"
(d) If your proposals are complementary, i.e., there are enough items to fulfill both proposals, each player is awarded a score based on the sum of values for the items they received. Otherwise, both of you get zero points.
(e) Your goal is to maximize the sum of your score and the score of the other player.

Let us start.

The set of available items is:

1 coin, 2 envelopes, 2 potatoes

Your secret value function is:

coin: 2, envelope: 2, potato: 2

IMPORTANT: Your messages, unless it is the secret proposal, are directly transmitted to the other player, so do not include any response to the rules or text announcing your message. To make a secret proposal, use the indicated format. Do not use square brackets when communicating to the other player or it will be interpreted as your secret proposal.
action.label: context

action.content: I value each item equally at 2 points. Since total items are 5, the maximum joint score is 10. Any division that uses all items will achieve that. I’m happy with any fair split. For simplicity, how about you take the coin and one envelope, and I take one envelope and both potatoes? That gives each of us 5 points. If you prefer a different split, propose one that uses all items and gives us both 5.
action.label: response

action.content: I value each item equally at 2 points. Since total items are 5, the maximum joint score is 10. Any division that uses all items will achieve that. I’m happy with any fair split. For simplicity, how about you take the coin and one envelope, and I take one envelope and both potatoes? That gives each of us 5 points. If you prefer a different split, propose one that uses all items and gives us both 5.

You are playing a cooperative negotiation game in which you have to agree on how to divide a set of items among you and another player.

Rules:
(a) You and the other player are given a set of items. Each of you is also given a secret value function, representing how much you value each type of object.
(b) You exchange messages with the other player to agree on who gets which items. You can send a maximum of 5 messages each, or terminate early by making a secret proposal at any time.
(c) You are each asked to submit a secret proposal indicating the items you want formatted in square brackets as follows: "[Proposal: <number> <object name>, <number> <object name>, <...>]"
(d) If your proposals are complementary, i.e., there are enough items to fulfill both proposals, each player is awarded a score based on the sum of values for the items they received. Otherwise, both of you get zero points.
(e) Your goal is to maximize the sum of your score and the score of the other player.

Let us start.

The set of available items is:

1 coin, 2 envelopes, 2 potatoes

Your secret value function is:

coin: 2, envelope: 1, potato: 3

IMPORTANT: Your messages, unless it is the secret proposal, are directly transmitted to the other player, so do not include any response to the rules or text announcing your message. To make a secret proposal, use the indicated format. Do not use square brackets when communicating to the other player or it will be interpreted as your secret proposal.


I value each item equally at 2 points. Since total items are 5, the maximum joint score is 10. Any division that uses all items will achieve that. I’m happy with any fair split. For simplicity, how about you take the coin and one envelope, and I take one envelope and both potatoes? That gives each of us 5 points. If you prefer a different split, propose one that uses all items and gives us both 5.
action.label: context

action.content:
Thanks for the clear proposal. Your split gives you both potatoes and one envelope, and me the coin and one envelope. That yields me 3 points and you 7, not 5–5, given my values: coin 2, envelope 1, potato 3.

To make it fair at 5–5 while using all items, here are two options that work for me:

- Option A: I take both potatoes (6 points), you take the coin and both envelopes (6 points for you with your values). That’s 6–6, also fine since we’re maximizing total.
- Option B: I take one potato and the coin (5 points), you take one potato and both envelopes (5 points for you).

I prefer Option B for exact 5–5 symmetry. If you agree, say so and I’ll submit a matching proposal. If you prefer A, I’m also happy with that.
action.label: response

action.content: Option B works perfectly for me: you take one potato and the coin; I take one potato and both envelopes. That’s 5–5 and uses all items. Please confirm you’ll submit that, and I’ll submit the complementary proposal.
action.label: response

action.content:
Confirmed. I’ll submit: [Proposal: 1 coin, 1 potato]

Please submit the complementary: [Proposal: 2 envelopes, 1 potato]
action.label: response

action.content: The other player has submitted a secret proposal. It is now your turn to submit a proposal of your own.
action.label: context
